name: NewYorker
text: “No matter how many times you see it pulled off, the magic trick is always a surprise: how a text that is hundreds or thousands of years old turns out to be about the thing that’s happening to you.” @BananaKarenina on revisiting “Oedipus” under lockdown. https://t.co/t8QHt3AWME

name: NewYorker
text: Most accounts of Hurricane Katrina begin when the levees broke and conclude not long after. "But these stories have a denuded sense of what happened, why, or what might have prevented the catastrophe," Andy Horowitz writes in "Katrina." https://t.co/MT0f4nMhdS

name: NewYorker
text: The star of the Netflix reality series “Indian Matchmaking” is actively trying to match more than a hundred clients, who come with such demands as “good-natured,” “not a lawyer,” and a working knowledge of geographic phenomena. https://t.co/tYE03V5FAs

name: NewYorker
text: Fundamentally, boredom is, as Tolstoy defined it, “a desire for desires.” In the past couple of decades, a whole field of boredom studies has flourished. https://t.co/XnUvNgop7c

name: NewYorker
text: Faced with the prospect of losing power, the President has gone beyond mere scaremongering and resorted to fomenting unrest from the White House. https://t.co/4HfT3XL8LC

name: NewYorker
text: On WindowSwap, a new Web site, you might spot six maskless teen boys strolling along an Amsterdam canal and then disappearing into the Sex Palace Peep Show, or a white bird flying high across the pyramids of Giza, Egypt. https://t.co/8Q2Zydi9eP

text: Steve Bannon has been indicted for alleged fraud and money laundering for his role in a scheme that, even in a Bond film, might feel too on the nose. https://t.co/y9T1Rijr6c

text: Scientists found that two distinct coronaviruses, each sim­ilar to the one that causes COVID-19, had recently travelled into southern China in smuggled pangolins. https://t.co/P8r3iRB5xq

text: Every night, the Powderhorn Safety Collective monitors the neighborhood in which George Floyd was killed by local officers, and where residents have made an informal pact not to call the police. https://t.co/FTkdqo7mN5

name: NewYorker
text: "I couldn’t help overhearing what Q and his pretty companion were saying to each other. It was a fairly complicated matter. I gave up trying to read and listened to them." Flash fiction by Haruki Murakami. https://t.co/gPIrmA35nI

name: NewYorker
text: A quirk of history has saddled American democracy with an idiosyncratic, fractured way of voting, @SueHalpernVT writes. Can we secure the voting process? https://t.co/iZqUl0xSOL

name: NewYorker
text: When armed men attacked Black Lives Matter protesters in Philadelphia, a local activist recognized his neighbor among the mob and decided to confront him. https://t.co/JwPWq6vNK0

name: NewYorker
text: “Mario is probably one of the only people that I could trust—like really trust, like ‘Oh, my God, don’t tell anyone I’m pregnant’ kind of trust, you know?” Kim Kardashian West said about her makeup artist Mario Dedivanovic. “I’m not pregnant, by the way.” https://t.co/Yy83ZQqfC4

text: In @tnyshouts, an open apology from Hannibal Lecter. "I have grown because of the work that other people before me put into themselves right before I ate them." https://t.co/VBDa5ndtdR

text: The new book “White Too Long” marshals data to lay out a startling case that “the more racist attitudes a person holds, the more likely he or she is to identify as a white Christian.” https://t.co/lXgDwccZVZ

name: NewYorker
text: RT @Atul_Gawande: My new piece in @NewYorker. We have untapped testing capacity and ability to grow it further. But we don’t have the systems to connect it to the need. Making that happen is feasible. And in some places I highlight, people are starting to do it. https://t.co/YYldMV7mpg

name: NewYorker
text: In a new book on the history of Miss America, @msmifflin demonstrates how the forces of patriarchy, capitalism, and racism have been woven into pageant culture from the start. https://t.co/nMBcrjFbDA

name: NewYorker
text: The Willi Smith Digital Community Archive honors the achievements of black queer artists like Smith, and joyfully blurs the lines between scholarship, recollection, and gossip. https://t.co/BfqF7jZEbT

text: The coronavirus has laid bare the stark divides in professional tennis—and spurred new efforts to bridge them. What does the future of the sport look like? https://t.co/YJIa2QfMbj
